title: 109_s1165
content: The Act may be cited as the "James Campbell National Wildlife Refuge Expansion Act of 2005". The United States Fish and Wildlife Service manages the James Campbell National Wildlife Refuge to promote the recovery of 4 endangered Hawaiian waterbirds. They lease 240 acres of wetland habitat and are purchasing the land to protect the endangered species and improve Refuge management. The United States Fish and Wildlife Service is purchasing land from the estate of James Campbell to protect endangered species habitat and improve Refuge management. The land features coastal dunes, wetlands, and strand that promote biological diversity for various species including endangered Hawaiian waterbirds, migratory shorebirds, waterfowl, and seabirds. The land being purchased from the estate of James Campbell will protect endangered species habitat and improve Refuge management. It features coastal dunes, wetlands, and strand that promote biological diversity for various species, including endangered Hawaiian waterbirds, migratory shorebirds, waterfowl, seabirds, endangered and native plant species, monk seals, and green sea turtles. Expanding the Refuge will provide increased opportunities for wildlife-dependent public uses like observation, photography, and environmental education. Acquisition of the land will create a single, large, manageable, and ecologically-intact unit with sufficient buffer land. The acquisition of land from the estate of James Campbell will create a large, ecologically-intact unit with buffer land to protect the Refuge from flood damage in Kahuku. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "Director" refers to the Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service. The term "Refuge" refers to the James Campbell National Wildlife Refuge established under the Endangered Species Act of 1973. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. Expansion of the James Campbell National Wildlife Refuge to include approximately 1,100 acres of land, with the Secretary authorized to make minor boundary modifications to achieve conservation goals or facilitate property acquisition. The map depicting the expansion is available for inspection at a designated office of the US Fish and Wildlife Service. The map showing the expansion of the James Campbell National Wildlife Refuge is available for inspection at a designated office of the US Fish and Wildlife Service, as determined by the Secretary. Notice of the map's availability will be published in the Federal Register and local publications. The Secretary may acquire land described in section 4(a) to become part of the Refuge and be administered according to applicable law. Sums necessary to carry out this Act are authorized to be appropriated.
